responses.content: AI and ML are broader, deeper investments that we are driving and using across our product portfolio. The recent launch of Tensor and Pixel 6 is a great example. We are willing to go as deep in the stack as needed, with silicon both on the cloud side with our Tensor Processing Units and on the client side with Google Tensor. We are thinking through compute, networking, building data centers, making sure they are clean and carbon-free, and investing in advanced models and algorithms. Additionally, we are looking into areas like quantum computing.

We see so much headroom, given our bet on AI. Going to our most important product of all, Search, when you see the launch of BERT, which was a significant improvement, and we are following that up with MUM, which is another extraordinary advance. So the rate information is growing – pretty rapidly, and so constantly developing better models to improve our search quality ranking, etc., is one of the most important ways we invest. Beyond that, all the work we are doing into making sure computers can understand in a multimodal way, be it images, audio, text, video, and then bringing it up across our products is an important approach.

On YouTube, we are deeply committed to supporting creators. We have seen significant growth in features like Super Chat, Channel Memberships, and the Shorts Fund. We are also exploring integrations with NFTs to enhance the creator experience. Our focus is on enabling creators to monetize their content effectively while providing engaging experiences for viewers. Additionally, we are investing in shopping capabilities on YouTube to integrate commerce seamlessly.

Shorts went global and now has 30 billion daily views, which is four times higher than a year ago. We have launched the YouTube Shorts Fund, which is available in over 100 countries, and over 40% of creators who received payments were not in the YouTube Partner Program. We are also testing ads on Shorts with products like App Install and Video Action campaigns and are encouraged by the early results. Our team is focused on closing the gap with traditional YouTube ads over time.

ruth_porat.role: Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer

responses.topic: Ad Business Growth and External Factors
responses.content: In terms of the Ad business, we were very pleased with the year-on-year Search revenue growth in the first quarter, up 24%. This reflected the strength we’ve seen in retail. However, this growth benefited from lapping the COVID-related weakness in 2020, which means we won’t have that tailwind moving forward. Additionally, our suspension of commercial activities in Russia and the impact of foreign exchange rates are factors we’re considering as we move into Q2 2022.

We are continuing to invest aggressively in Google Cloud, focusing on expanding our global footprint, increasing compute capacity, and enhancing our product offerings. Our recent addition of a second Cloud region in India underscores our commitment. We are also investing in cybersecurity and multi-cloud support as key differentiators. Our approach remains centered on revenue growth and long-term value creation.

We have increased our share repurchase program authorization to $50 billion and are executing against it. We view share repurchases as incrementally valuable and continue to allocate capital towards it. Regarding our cost structure, while operating margins remain strong at around 30%, this is primarily due to strong revenue growth. We continue to invest in headcount, technical infrastructure, and other strategic areas to support long-term growth.

responses.topic: Impact of Geopolitical Events on Revenue
responses.content: The war in Ukraine has had an impact on our advertising revenues, particularly in Europe and Russia. We suspended most of our commercial activities in Russia, which accounted for about 1% of our 2021 revenues, primarily from advertising. Additionally, there was a pull-back in advertiser spend on YouTube in Europe due to the conflict.

We continue to focus on investing for long-term growth while maintaining operational excellence. This includes investing in technical infrastructure, improving productivity, and enhancing our systems to support product teams. Our hybrid work model necessitates continued investment in office facilities globally, supporting our growing headcount.

philipp_schindler.role: Senior Vice President and Chief Business Officer

responses.content: Performance Max brings together Google’s automation to help advertisers maximize reach and efficiency across our channels. We have introduced new features, including customer acquisition goals, campaign-level insights, and a one-click upgrade tool for Smart Shopping and Local campaigns. We are committed to helping Performance Max deliver maximum value and are focused on generating optimal performance for our advertising partners. Adoption timelines remain consistent with previous rollouts, focusing on delivering maximum value and performance.

Shorts went global and now has 30 billion daily views, four times higher than a year ago. We have launched the YouTube Shorts Fund, available in over 100 countries, with over 40% of creators receiving payments not previously in the YouTube Partner Program. We are also testing ads on Shorts with products like App Install and Video Action campaigns and are encouraged by early results. Our focus is on supporting the next generation of mobile creators and enhancing monetization options.

We have removed financial barriers by making listings free and eliminating commission fees, which resulted in a 50% lift in clicks for merchants using both free listings and Shopping Ads. We have focused on removing integration barriers through partnerships with platforms like Shopify, Square, BigCommerce, GoDaddy, and WooCommerce. Our goal is to simplify the onboarding process for merchants and enhance their advertising capabilities across Search, Shopping, Image Search, and YouTube.

We are expanding advertising opportunities on YouTube by integrating shopping capabilities and enhancing direct response options. Features like creator tagging, shopping live streams with brands like Walmart and Target, and product feeds in Video Action Campaigns are in pilot stages. We are also exploring monetization within Shorts and testing how shopping can be integrated with Shorts to drive conversions.

We are committed to privacy-preserving technologies like the Privacy Sandbox to replace third-party cookies. Our latest proposal, Topics API, allows advertisers to show relevant ads based on user interests inferred from browsing behavior in a privacy-preserving manner. This initiative aims to sustain a healthy, ad-supported web while respecting user privacy.

questions: Could you talk to us at all about sort of the shape of the Ad business growth throughout the first quarter, understanding there’s some uncertainty around Ukraine, et cetera.
What have you seen sort of quarter to date in the overall Search business from a growth perspective?

Other industry players have called out pockets of weakness in brand advertising globally in the quarter that you just reported. Did you see any of that from a volatility standpoint, especially around maybe the war in Ukraine for a period of time in March?

How should we be thinking about the strategic goals of driving longer engagement and user growth and monetization for YouTube against some of the initiatives you called out? Versus how to think about the performance of the business as we go through ’22, short-form video versus long-form video, or maybe mix of direct-response versus brand advertising?

Just thinking about industry conversations, it seems pretty clear that you’re able to capture some dollars that shifted to Search from social related to Apple’s iOS privacy changes. Just curious if that dynamic continued in 1Q.
Can you comment at all just how you think about sustainability of those dollars going forward?

In terms of spending and on the margin side, operating margins continue to be strong at 30%, even with the greater headcount of the past couple quarters. Can you elaborate on what you mean by “considered investments” and in what areas are you able to offset and gain more efficiencies in the business?
Has the ramp in Shorts activity been a little bit of a headwind for growth as you ramped that up?

When you think about regulation in Europe, there’s a lot of headlines about the Digital Markets Act and other things. How do you think about the regulatory environment and the evolution over the next couple years?

Google Analytics is transitioning to a new version and sunsetting the older version next year. Can you elaborate on these changes, how they relate to the deprecation of cookies in Chrome, and how you plan to ensure a smooth transition?
You mentioned strong performance in subscriptions. Are there any products driving that strength in particular?
Do you feel like Travel has come back full or is Travel still sort of underperforming for macro reasons versus where it was pre-COVID?
Regarding share repurchases, how should we think about these going forward? To what extent is it opportunistic versus systematic or systemic in your approach to returning cash to shareholders?
Are you seeing any meaningful shift in consumer demand for the mobile YouTube product due to TikTok? Any shift in advertising because of TikTok?
Is there anything you want to call out about Asia Pacific this quarter, why it could have been softer? Or any other product that may have led to a bit of a slower quarter for APAC?

topics: Next Billion Users and Product Direction
questions: Can you talk about whether we should continue to be looking overseas to think about what direction you might take across your various products and services?

If I take your ad dollars, this quarter $50 billion and annualize, it’s like $200 billion a year. Are you or the board focused at all on trying to diversify away from the ad market or do you just feel like there’s so much runway that there is no real reason to stay focused on non-ad-based growth?

operating_environment_challenges: Impact of Ukraine war on advertising revenues
Suspension of commercial activities in Russia
Privacy changes affecting advertising spend (e.g., Apple iOS changes)
Regulatory scrutiny in Europe (Digital Markets Act)
Scaling and adoption of Performance Max and other advertising tools
Sustainability initiatives and content responsibility on YouTube
Transitioning Google Analytics amidst cookie deprecation
